Award.AwardTitle: The Science Underpinning Anomalous Scaling Laws of Strength and Toughness in Nanocellulose Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The quest of materials possessing both high strength and high toughness is perpetual in advanced material design. Unfortunately, these two mechanical properties are generally mutually exclusive. For example, for metals and alloys, their toughness is usually inversely proportional to their strength. As a result, in practice, the design of strong and tough materials is inevitably a compromise. So far, a general and feasible mechanism to address the conflict of strength vs. toughness still remains elusive. This project plans to shed insight on a possible strategy resolving the conflict of strength vs. toughness by investigating the fundamental science of the anomalous but desirable scaling law of mechanical properties of cellulose nanopaper: both its strength and toughness increase as the cellulose fiber size decreases. These unique features combined with the intrinsic biodegradability, low-cost and scalable manufacturing of cellulose paper can have significant impact on bottom-up design of high performance materials with desirable mechanical properties.

The research plan will be carried out in a systematic framework integrating multi-scale mechanics modeling and complementary experiments and consists of two thrusts. The overarching goal of Thrust 1 is to establish a quantitative understanding of the underpinning mechanism of both strong and tough cellulose nanopaper, by investigating the mechanics of cellulose molecular chains, nanofibrillated cellulose fibers and cellulose fiber network via multi-scale mechanics modeling and complementary experiments. The fundamental understanding from Thrust 1 will lay out a solid foundation that motivates and enables the research efforts in Thrust 2, which focuses on generalizing the underpinning mechanism of attaining both strength and toughness to guide the exploration of a class of strong and tough materials with other highly desirable multi-functionalities. Interdisciplinary graduate student training will enable to access world-class imaging and metrology facilities at NIST, and to learn from the vast expertise and state-of the-art technology from a world leading paper company. Outreach activities will be conducted via iMechanica.org, the largest international online community of mechanics with 50,000+ registered users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced the understanding of the fundamental mechanisms that lead to the high strength and toughness of cellulose nanopaper. The scientific findings on the strengthening and toughening mechanisms were then applied to guide the design of a new class of strong and tough materials with other highly desirable multi-functions. 

Intellectual merit:

This project provided new fundamental insight on addressing a long-sought solution in advanced material design: attaining strength and toughness simultaneously. The fundamental understanding of the strong and tough cellulose nanopaper reveals a bottom-up strengthening and toughening mechanism that can be generally applicable to a wide range of material building blocks, which in turn opens up fertile opportunities toward a new class of materials with both exceptional mechanical properties and other highly desirable features (e.g., sustainable, low-cost, and multifunctional). Specifically, this project led to the following advances in science and technology:

  1. While the high strength of cellulose nanopaper stems from the significantly reduced defect size and density in building blocks, its high toughness finds its origin from the facile formation of hydrogen bonding among cellulose molecular chains and the cascade of hydrogen bond forming-breaking-reforming events during the failure process of cellulose nanopaper, which dissipate significant amount of energy and thus lead to enhanced toughness. These findings are applicable to many other material systems and suggest a universal bottom-up design strategy toward strong and tough materials.
  2. Based on the mechanistic findings obtained from cellulose nanopaper, we applied the design strategy to develop two new types of microfibers with high performance mechanical properties. First, we hybridized graphene oxide flakes and cellulose nanofibers into carbon microfibers and found that such bybrid microfibers are both stronger and tougher than pure graphene oxide fiber and pure cellulose microfibers; Second, we explored cellulose nanofiber enabled 3D printing of carbon nanotube microfiber network with a combination of high mechanical strength and high conductivity.
  3. We established a bottom-up and scalable coarse grained modeling scheme, which allows for efficient simulations of cellulose fibers of real size in experimental design with insights at molecular scale bonding nature. We also established a crack-bridging mechanics model on toughening mechanism of cellulose nanopaper, with particular focus on identifying key parameters that govern the failure mechanics of cellulose nanopaper and determining their quantitative correlation with the fracture toughness. These advances in modeling scheme could offer potential insights and guidelines and thus accelerate the discovery of a new class of engineering materials that are both strong and tough.

Broader Impact:

The need for sustainable low-cost materials with exceptional multi-functionalities is ubiquitous. Cellulose is the most abundant biopolymer on earth and has long been used as the sustainable building block for paper. The research findings in this project year can shed cruical light on radically changing the conventional thinking of wood­based paper: it can be made strong and tough, ultra­transparent, highly electrically conductive, or electrochemically active. These multifunctional paper with high strength and toughness can lead to a range of emerging applications, e.g., light­weight electric conductors, wearable electronics, conformal batteries, optical films and thermal conductors. Furthermore, the fundamental design strategy learned from the research findings can be generally applicable and adapted to other material systems, and thus holds promise to open novel pathways to a wide range of new multifunctional nanocomposites with superb mechanical properties, which can potentially enable many advanced structural and device applications. 

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2017
Modified by: Teng Li

The fundamental understanding of the strong and tough cellulose nanopaper reveals a bottom-up strengthening and toughening mechanism that can be generally applicable to a wide range of material building blocks, which in turn opens up fertile opportunities toward a new class of materials with both exceptional mechanical properties and other highly desirable features (e.g., sustainable, low-cost, and multifunctional).
